item.title: R Statistics T-test
item.description: R Series 5 Functions qt(), and t.test() Ah t-tests, A t-test is normally an analysis of two populations means through the use of statistical examination; a t-test with two samples is commonly used with small sample sizes, testing the difference between the samples when the variances of two normal distributions are not known. However, there is such a thing as a one sample t-test. The one sample t-test is a statistical procedure used to determine whether a sample of observations could have been generated by a process with a specific mean.

item.title: R Series Proabailities with normal data
item.description: R Series 4 Function pnorm() Let’s talk about normally distributed data. Normally distributed data is the unachievable unicorn, it’s like Kristaps Porzingas, you do everything that you can to get it, but it rarely ever occurs in nature. Normally distributed data is a perfect bell curve and is statistically predictable.Its probability is predictable through a function in R called pnorm. Let’s supposed that a study found that foot lengths for Japanese women are normally distributed with a mean of 24.

item.title: R Basics seq(), rep(), and standard deviation with basic functions
item.description: R Series 3 Functions seq(),rep(), and standard deviation In the last post we went over significant functions like mean() and diff() this post will examine the seq() or sequence function, the rep() or repeat function, and a way to calculate standard deviation with basic functions. First, we will examine the sequence function. The sequence function runs by inputing two numbers seperated by a comma in the parenthesis. You then have the option of inputing parameters.

item.title: R Basics combine
item.description: R Series These posts will follow everything I have learned or stumbled upon during my time in Mercyhurst’s Data Science program. This first function is called combine and it is launched by using this line of code c(). As demonstrated below, the combine function combines all the data within the parenthesis into a list and that list is stored within the designated variable. x<- c(1,5,7,15) x ## [1] 1 5 7 15

item.title: R basics length(), diff(), mean()
item.description: R Series 2 Functions length(), diff(), and mean() Last post we examined the use of the combine funtion to throw an array of numbers into a variable. Now we will examine some functions that actually affect the array. First, we will look at the function length(). To do so we will need a list of numbers. Since I am a big baseball guy, I used Chicago Cub’s first basemen, Anthony Rizzo’s, home runs over his last five seasons.

item.title: Test Post
item.description: This is just a test post let’s add some libraries: library(Lahman) library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union Now how about a query: Batting%>% select(playerID,HR)%>% filter(HR>50) ## playerID HR ## 1 ruthba01 54 ## 2 ruthba01 59 ## 3 ruthba01 60 ## 4 ruthba01 54 ## 5 wilsoha01 56 ## 6 foxxji01 58 ## 7 greenha01 58 ## 8 kinerra01 51 ## 9 mizejo01 51 ## 10 kinerra01 54 ## 11 mayswi01 51 ## 12 mantlmi01 52 ## 13 mantlmi01 54 ## 14 marisro01 61 ## 15 mayswi01 52 ## 16 fostege01 52 ## 17 fieldce01 51 ## 18 mcgwima01 52 ## 19 griffke02 56 ## 20 griffke02 56 ## 21 mcgwima01 70 ## 22 sosasa01 66 ## 23 mcgwima01 65 ## 24 sosasa01 63 ## 25 bondsba01 73 ## 26 gonzalu01 57 ## 27 rodrial01 52 ## 28 sosasa01 64 ## 29 rodrial01 57 ## 30 thomeji01 52 ## 31 jonesan01 51 ## 32 howarry01 58 ## 33 ortizda01 54 ## 34 rodrial01 54 ## 35 bautijo02 54 ## 36 davisch02 53
